prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA for getting mad at my boyfriend for being too gentle during sex? (nsfw)
I (21F) and my boyfriend (26M) have been dating for a few months and have been having sex regularly. We talked beforehand about our likes and dislikes, and I told him that I don’t like sex to feel too gentle or passionate and that it makes me uncomfortable. I know it’s strange but I was in an abusive relationship before and I’ve found that when I have rough sex I can sort of let go and have fun but when it’s gentle and about connection I get all in my head and I get really uncomfortable and I hate it.

Last night we were gearing up to have sex, and he said he wanted to have “normal” sex, and when I asked what he meant he started kissing my body a lot which I didn’t really like.  I told him I didn’t like it and he stopped but he kept trying to do cutesy things like playing with my hair and chaste kisses and stuff, and I got mad at him and told him to stop. I didn’t really say much I just put my clothes on and left.

I haven’t answered his messages today. AITA?
"""

Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's try to figure out if the author is in the wrong here. The user is a 21-year-old woman who's dating a 26-year-old man. They've been together a few months and have sex regularly. She mentioned that she told him before she doesn't like gentle or passionate sex because of her past abusive relationship. She prefers rough sex to feel comfortable. 

In the situation, she says he wanted to have "normal" sex, which I guess he took as gentle. He started kissing her body, which she didn't like. She told him to stop, he did, but then he kept doing cutesy things like playing with her hair and chaste kisses. She got mad, put clothes on, and left. She hasn't responded to his messages.

First, she communicated her preferences beforehand. He might not have fully understood "normal" as being gentle, but he did start doing things she didn't like. When she told him to stop, he stopped but then continued with other actions she didn't like. She got upset and left. 

Her reaction could be justified because she was clear about her boundaries. He didn't respect her when she told him to stop after the first time. Maybe he thought he could adjust, but she felt uncomfortable again. She left because she couldn't handle it, which is her right. 

On the other hand, maybe he was trying to be affectionate and didn't realize she was still uncomfortable. But since she had a history and told him her preferences, he should have adjusted. Her getting mad is a reaction to her discomfort, not just being difficult. 

So, the author isn't in the wrong because she communicated her needs and he didn't follow through after she asked him to stop. He might be in the wrong for not respecting her boundaries. Therefore, answer B.
